bibl.title: Letter from Laura Armistead Carter to William S. Thayer, May 19, 1931

div1.p: Laura Carter comments on her financial situation and mentions her brother Edward, who is in a sanitarium.

div1.head: Letter from Laura Armistead Carter to William S. Thayer, May 19, 1931

opener.dateline:
The Westmoreland,
2122 California St., N. W.,
Washington, D. C.
May 19, 1931

div1.p:
If circumstances occur according to your so=kind hope that you
can, in the natural course of conversation, speak of me to Dr. Russell,
it may be well for me to recapitulate for you a few points: not with any
idea of your taking up matters in extenso, but for your own information.

When I wrote you last September, in compliance with your request
to learn how things would be with me on the completion of the book, I
told you that Father had hoped to leave me about $235.00 a month. Indeed,
I did have nearly that amount. Last September, at the time I wrote you,
my income had been reduced to about $125.00 a month, of which $20.00 a
month had to be put aside for taxes. This income is now still further
reduced as I found I could not continue to live and work on the book
during the past winter and spring without continuing to go into my capi-
tal. When my cousin, Mr. H. Carter Redd, sent me my last check for my
expenses for May. he wrote that, after drawing it, there remained a bal-
ance of $25.41 to my credit in the Richmond bank. I trust that he may be
able to collect some more money before my June expenses must be met. How-
ever, I have written him asking if this be impossible, to try to borrows
enough on my securities to keep things afloat until the lease for this
apartment is up (August 31st.) Naturally, the loan will also have to be
deducted from my principal when enough of it becomes available. That he
will have to negociate such a loan seems inevitable, since even if he
does manage to collect enough money for my monthly expenses through August
there will still have to be additional money raised for me to do the thing
I least wish to do--break up the remanant of what I have called “home”
and dispose of possessions, of little intrinsic value 'tis true, but
precious to me from association and the assurance that so long as I had
them I retained the personal privacy and independance of which they were
“the outward and visible sign.”

I am sure that Dr. Russell has meant to be more than just, that
it has been his intention to be both kind and generous in the matter of
the work on the book. Also, he had me on the payroll far longer than
either he or I anticipated. That the earlier completion of the book would
have been to my financial advantage, as well as his, sounds strange, but
my whole manner of living had to be so changed, on account of the pres-
sure of the work, my own poor health (prohibiting the “cross-cuts” and
economies of most women in moderate circumstances) had family responsi-
bilities, which had to be met with money (as I had no time available for
anything save the book) that the longer I worked the less I had. Of
course, the Rockefeller pay (and later, half pay) were a god-send, and
it has been much harder since the half pay stopped (Dec. 1929). My long
sick leaves without pay (and with greatly increased expense) had, of
course, to come out of my capital.

FromAt the time of Father's death, my younger brother was in a sani-
tarium, where he was very unhappy, and which was becoming increasingly
expensive (beyong what could be met with the interest on the money Father
left in trust for him). I made up the deficit, as I felt it would be
impossible for me to take enough time and thought from the book to inves-
tigate other places and find one more suitable for him. I also gave him
additional money for incidental expenses, in order to make things a little
more endurable for him until I could carry out my promise to him of mov-
mov-
-2-
ing him to another place: “Just so soon as the book” should be
finished. Finally, after several years of waiting, he took matters in
his own hands and ran away. It was a great shock, but a mercy in the end,
as he is now in a sanitarium where he no longer needs my help. The money
Father left for his care is amply sufficient there. This is a great
relief, as I should deplore having him suffer from lack of the things
I used to to be able to do for him.

Another thing: In the pressure of the work on the book, I did
not feel justified to take off even enough time to make out vouchers
for my incidental expenses in connection with the work. These, in the
spring, summer and fall of 1928 sometimes exceeded my half pay salary:
taxis to and from the Library with books and other heavy material: Miss
Brown's meals when we were working together: travelling expenses to
Baltimore etc. etc. Being assured, however, that the book would be com-
pleted that fall or winter, I was more than willing to meet the financial
loss in order to have more time for Miss Brown and myself to push our
work on the book. I was always promptly reimbursed by the International
Health Division for the few incidental expenses that I reported.

I have no claim and no complaint to make. I am quite sure, how-
ever, that Dr. Russell has never had a chance to realize what the book
has cost me, and will continue to cost, in the loss of financial se-
curity and of living as Father so happily and confidently felt that he
had arranged that I should live after his death. He greatly wanted me
to be free to go back to my own writing and rejoiced that he had se-
cured me “a future free from the obligation of having to do routine work
for a living.” The time left for my own work is already much shortened.
Whether I shall be free to use any of what remains is a question. Still,
the thought of the passing of time also brings a solace o' sorts. Remem-
ber the legend of Solomon's seal?

With happiest recollections of that glimpse through “the Door to
Paradise” last Saturday afternoon!
div1.closer:
Ever yours, Laura A. Carter
P. S. Sorry for the appearance of this letter, but my typewriter
needs drastic repairs. I had a man come up and make an estimate which was
appalling. We “compromised” on a new ribbon.
L. A. C.
